Amines Plant No. 1 - U.S. Amines:



The plant is subject to and operated in accordance with OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) regulations and the EPA-RMP program.  The site maintains one PSM plan which includes application of the OSHA PSM rule and the EPA-RMP rule.  Amines Plant No. 1 includes the following RMP listed chemicals above the RMP threshold:



1.  Ammonia

2.  Isopropylamine



Ammonia



Operations of the storage locations for ammonia and the operations using ammonia fall under the site PSM program.  Ammonia is stored as a liquefied gas.  There are three storage tanks for pure ammonia which do not have storage containment dikes because dikes would not contain the ammonia from evaporation.  Storage for ammonia within the process unit does include dikes as the ammonia stored in the process is not pure and dikes would contain some of the material that would not immediately evaporate. The storage areas are serviced by fire water spray nozzles that would be used in the event of a large spill.  Ammonia is readily soluble in water and water would be effective in mitigating a large spill.



Isopropylamine



Operations of the storage locations and production of isopropylamine fall under the site PSM program.  The storage locations are covered by automatic and/or manual fire suppression systems.  The storage areas are curbed or diked with hold-up volume adequate to contain all of the tank contents.  The storage areas are serviced by fire water spray nozzles that would be used in the event of a large spill.  Isopropylamine is readily soluble in water and water would be effective in mitigating a large spill.



The site PSM program has policies that go beyond the OSHA PSM and EPA-RMP rules.  Some of those policies are listed below:



1.  Sight glass use: Sight glass use is discouraged in hazardous chemical service.  In cases where sight level indicators are needed, magnetically coupled, metal gauges are used or other provisions are made to protect against releases from breakage.

2.  Quarter-turn valves (1" size or less) are fitted with oval handles to reduce the risk of releases from bumping a straight handle valve open.

3.  Qualitative risk assessment is incorporated into our PHA and MOC process in order to provide more consistent evaluation of risk.  This provides better guidance in reducing risk, over the HAZOP only type of analysis.

4.  The plant belongs to and participates in the Mobile County EMA, the local county emergency planning committee.  The plant also participates in the local Lemoyne Community Advisory Panel (LCAP), a group of local chemical and industrial facilities that meet with the community several times per year to discuss safety and risk management issues within the local industrial park.

5.  All operators are trained and certified in the jobs they perform.

6.  All employees have the authority to shut down any process or stop any job, in order to maintain safe operation.

7.  Employee training programs covers job specific tasks, principles of chemical engineering, safety, and regulatory issues.  This includes: monthly safety meetings, monthly computer based training classes, annual and tri-annual training and recertification programs.

8.  All plant operators are trained in emergency response.

9.  The plant has an extensive fire fighting system with monitor nozzles, hoses, foam generating capability and water reservoir.

10.  The plant has a portable emergency command vehicle complete with air monitoring equipment, radio and cellular phone systems, emergency response and decontamination materials.

11.  The plant alarm system and fire water systems are tested weekly.

12.  Emergency response personnel are trained in first aid and CPR.

The vapor space of the storage tank is purged with nitrogen to prevent the formation of an explosive atmosphere condition.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Program Overview:



At US Amines, we are dedicated to being an industry leader in protecting the environment, the health, and safety of both our employees and the communities in which we operate.  Like our local community and industrial neighbors, the people who work at the Bucks plant want a clean, safe environment, with no illnesses or injuries at work, home, or play.  That is why US Amines has a "zero incidents" goal.  We are committed to reducing emissions and continuously improving our performance toward zero injuries and zero environmental incidents.



The US Amines Bucks Plant participates in a local community advisory panel and works with other area industrial facilities to promote safety in our operations.  The Lemoyne Community Advisory Panel was one of the first community advisory panels established in the United States.  The Lemoyne Industrial Park companies have been recognized by local, state, and national organizations for outstanding cooperation.  This continued partnership ensures that the community where we all live and work will be a safe place now and in the future.



Our Facility and Substances Handled:



We manufacture several different chemicals called alkyl amines.  Our products are used to produce agricultural chemicals, water treatment chemicals, and drugs.  Our Isopropylamine is a chemical combination of isopropyl alcohol (the same chemical as in rubbing alcohol) and ammonia (the same chemical as in home floor cleaning products).  This is sold to other chemical manufacturers who make herbicides and agriculture products like the popular home and farm product, RoundUp.  The chemicals that we handle and report on include the following RMP listed chemicals: ammonia, isopropylamine, cyclohexylamine, and propionitrile.  We have about 50 site employees (about 35 company employees and 15 resident contractors).



Plant Safety Activities and Release Prevention Program:



The plant has a plant manager who oversees all plant activities.  The sta

ff includes an occupational safety manager, process safety manager, environmental manager, production engineers, and maintenance engineers.  All plant employees must attend at least one safety meeting per month.  Safety meetings include training on regulatory requirements and plant specific issues.  Testing is conducted in safety meetings to insure the information is understood.  The plant conducts monthly self-paced computer based training on regulatory safety topics which includes testing to demonstrate comprehension.  Plant operators and other employees are members of the Bucks Emergency Services Team (BEST team) that has the capability of handling most foreseeable incidents.  Mutual aid agreements with other local industrial sites and local fire and emergency response agencies complement the emergency response plan.  The BEST team members are trained in the specifics of incident command, emergency response, rope rescue, and medical response.  The plant conducts weekly tests of the plant alarm system and conducts emergency response drills with local industrial facilities, local fire departments, and the county emergency response team, Mobile County EMA.



The US Amines Bucks plant complies with RMP and OSHA 1910.119, (the OSHA Process Safety Regulation) through our consolidated Process Safety Management Program.  The Bucks plant manages all plant processes per our Process Safety Management program.  The program meets all of the RMP and OSHA requirements such as:



*  Develop and implement a risk management system.

*  Conduct hazard assessments of all processes.

*  Implement accident prevention requirements.

*  Develop an emergency response program that is coordinated with local agencies.

*  Track and analyze incidents to prevent reoccurrence.



Plant 5-Year Accident History: 



RMP reporting requires us to tell the public about accidents involving the listed chemicals that resulted in injuries or serious on-site or off-site impact.  The plant has had no r

eportable accidents in the past five years.  The plant had had no reportable accidents since US Amines began operations in 2003.  The good safety record goes back even further when the business was owned by another company.



How We Keep Our Plant Safe and Planned Safety Improvements:



People:  Our Most Valuable Safety Resource



1.  All plant operators are trained and certified in the jobs they do.

2.  All employees have the authority to shut down any process or stop any job, in order to maintain safe operation.

3.  Employee training programs cover job specific tasks, principles of chemical processing, safety, and regulatory issues.

 

Equipment:  Maintained in Safe Condition



1.  All plant process equipment is subjected to mechanical integrity inspections to look for corrosion or wear.

2.  Safety devices such as pressure relief valves and shutdown systems are inspected and tested on a regular basis.

3.  The use of thermal imagery cameras allow us to check for temperature deviations in equipment, check for electrical faults, and verify levels.

4.  Glass level gauges have been replaced with metal, magnetically-coupled gauges to remove the risk of spills from broken glass gauges.



Safety Systems:  Protective Safety Net



1.  All storage tanks and process vessels are protected against over-pressure by safety relief valves, much like the safety relief valve on your home water heater.

2.  Process safety systems are programmed in our process control computers.  If a designated level, pressure, temperature, or other parameter goes out of range, the process will shut down automatically.

3.  Process gas analyzers protect the integrity of key equipment including various boiler, compressor, and reactor operations.

4.  All plant modifications and procedure changes undergo a management of change process that involves operations, maintenance, engineering, and management review.

5.  The plant has taken advantage of new technology in the process control field as

it becomes available.  The advent of wireless technology is a good example.  This has allowed us to install monitoring instrumentation which was not possible in previous years to help improve operation and reduce unscheduled outages.



Prepared:  For Emergency Response



1.  All plant operators are trained in emergency response, fire fighting, and must pass a physical agility test.

2.  The plant has an extensive fire fighting system with monitor nozzles, hoses, foam generating capability, and water reservoir. 

3.  The plant has a portable emergency command vehicle complete with air monitoring equipment, radio and cellular phone systems, emergency response, and decontamination materials.

4.  The plant alarm system is tested weekly to ensure that employees know how to use it.

5.  Emergency response personnel are trained in first aid and CPR.
